explanations.summary: Central chemoreceptors respond to CSF/brain pH changes caused by CO2. Increased arterial pCO2 → CO2 diffuses into CSF → H⁺ increases (pH drops) → stimulates breathing. They DON'T respond to O2 levels or venous blood.

whyCorrect.c: Reduced arterial pH (acidosis) stimulates central chemoreceptors. CO2 crosses blood-brain barrier → forms H⁺ in CSF → detected by medullary chemoreceptors → increases ventilation.
whyCorrect.d: Increased arterial pCO2 is the PRIMARY stimulus. CO2 readily diffuses across BBB, converts to H⁺ in CSF, stimulating central chemoreceptors to increase respiration.

whyIncorrect.a: INCREASED pH (alkalosis) would DECREASE respiratory drive, not increase it.
whyIncorrect.b: Central chemoreceptors don't respond to venous pO2. They detect arterial/CSF changes, not venous.
whyIncorrect.e: INCREASED brain interstitial pH (alkalosis) would decrease respiratory drive. It's DECREASED pH that stimulates.
whyIncorrect.f: Central chemoreceptors respond primarily to CO2/H⁺, NOT oxygen. Peripheral chemoreceptors (carotid/aortic bodies) detect O2.
